We also find that social media reactions can be used to predict future visitation patterns early and accurately. \  \ We validate our methods using qualitative analysis as well as quantitative analysis on data from a large international news network, for a set of articles generating more than 3,000,000 visits and 200,000 social media reactions. We show that it is possible to model accurately the overall traffic articles will ultimately receive by observing the first ten to twenty minutes of social media reactions. Achieving the same prediction accuracy with visits alone would require to wait for three hours of data. We also describe significant improvements on the accuracy of the early prediction of shelf-life for news stories.

column3: Hidden Affinities: Inferring Opportunities for Serendipitous Introductions
column9: Julia Mayer, Chris Markson, Quentin (Gad) Jones
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Location-based and context-aware computing; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Every day people miss out on numerous opportunities to make new connections with interesting people around them. This paper introduces new approaches to identifying opportunities for computer-mediated introductions based on situated social context and social inferences. People’s openness and motivation to meet new people in various places and situations was explored through an interview study. Findings extracted from an analysis of 46 interviews outline the relationship between users’ current context, openness to meet people, affinity strength, and matching opportunities. We propose several new innovative design concepts for opportunistic social matching systems including contextual rarity, contextual oddity, contextual sociability and skill/attitude matching.

column3: How to See Values in Social Computing: Methods for Studying Values Dimensions
column9: Katie Shilton, Jes A. Koepfler, Kenneth R. Fleischmann
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Human values play an important role in understanding social computing. Research on values in social computing is challenged by disagreement about indicators and objects of study as researchers distribute their focus across contexts of technology design, adoption, and use. This paper draws upon a framework that clarifies how to see values in social computing research by describing values dimensions, comprised of sources and attributes of values in sociotechnical systems. This paper uses the framework to compare how diverse research methods employed in social computing surface values and make them visible to researchers. The framework provides a tool to analyze the strengths and weaknesses of each method for observing values dimensions. By detailing how and where researchers might observe interactions between values and technology design and use, we hope to enable researchers to systematically identify and investigate values in social computing.

column3: Understanding factors of successful engagement around energy consumption between and among households
column9: Tawanna Dillahunt, Jennifer Mankoff
column100: Other domain-specific support; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: An increasing number of researchers are using social engagement techniques such as neighborhood comparison and competition to encourage energy conservation, yet community reception and experience with such systems have not been well studied. We also find that researchers have not thoroughly investigated how different households use these systems and how their uses differ from one another. We explore these questions in a 4-10 month field deployment of a social-energy monitoring application across 15 households, in two distinct locations. We contribute results that describe conditions under which these techniques were effective and ineffective. Our results imply that understanding factors such as a building, or community’s layout, context knowledge of community members, accountability and adherence to social norms, trust, and length of residence are key for future design of social-energy applications.

column3: Can Plans and Situated Actions be Replicated?
column9: John Rooksby
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Legal/historical/philosophical aspects; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: This paper recreates and discusses the study of photocopier use originally presented in Suchman’s book Plans and Situated Actions. There are often complaints about the lack of replication studies in disciplines related to CSCW (particularly Software Engineering and HCI). However, these complaints are usually embedded in wider attempts to install a principled scientific method within these disciplines. Plans and Situated Actions was not a scientific text but drew upon naturalistic analysis. This paper argues there has been value in recreating Plans and Situated Actions (specifically in being able to explore laboratory issues unexplored in the original, and in understanding the book as being about more than instruction following). However the paper argues that recreating the study has not and cannot constitute a scientific replication. The paper concludes that recreating studies should not be conflated with replication.

column3: Monitoring Email to Indicate Project Team Performance and Mutual Attraction
column9: Sean Munson, Karina Kervin, Lionel Robert
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Many managers and mentors for project teams desire more efficient and more effective ways of monitoring and predicting the quality of social relationships and the performance of teams under their purview. A previous study found that one form of linguistic mimicry, linguistic style matching, and some lexical features indicated team performance and mutual attraction in short-term, laboratory tasks. In this paper, we evaluate whether these measures also work as indicators for performance, shared understanding, and team trust in longer-duration project teams, using only limited, unobtrusively obtained communication traces. In our four-month evaluation using student project team emails, we found no support for LSM or most of the previously identified measures as practical indicators in our field setting. We did find some support for using future-oriented words to predict team performance over time.

column3: Achieving Convergence in Operational Transformation: Conditions, Mechanisms and Systems
column9: YI XU, Chengzheng Sun
column100: Concurrency control
column101: In this paper, we present a comprehensive and in-depth study on convergence property preservation and avoidance in Operational Transformation (OT) systems. In this study, we discovered general and special conditions, transformation patterns, and basic mechanisms for avoiding Convergence Property 2 (CP2), and established the CP2-avoidance correctness of seven major OT systems. Furthermore, we proposed improvements to existing systems and designed a new OT system with a combination of novel features, which is unique and nonexistent in any existing system. These results are significant contributions to the advancement of fundament OT knowledge and technology and to collaboration-enabling technology.

column3: Exhaustive and Efficient Search of Puzzles in Operational Transformation
column9: Chengzhyeng Sun, Yi Xu
column100: Concurrency control
column101: Operational Transformation (OT) is a collaboration-enabling technology and has been a technical research topic in CSCW in over two decades. One main challenge in OT research is detecting and resolving puzzles – subtle and characteristic scenarios in which an OT system may fail. After many years of extensive search and research, various intricate puzzles have been detected and resolved. However, it remains open whether all puzzles have been discovered. To solve this issue, we set out to devise a system of verification frameworks and a software tool, that are independent of specific OT algorithms and able to exhaustively cover all possible transformation cases in which puzzles (if any) will manifest themselves. With the support of these tools, we verified OT correctness and concluded: all puzzles, under basic data and operation models and established transformation properties, have been discovered and resolved. These results are significant as they resolved a number of long-standing OT mysteries and contributed to the advancement of OT fundamental knowledge and technological innovation.

column3: Enriching the Distressing Reality: Social Media Use by Chinese Migrant Workers
column9: Jingjing Liu, Alexander Boden, David Randall, Volker Wulf
column42: University of Siegen and Fraunhofer FIT
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: Based on a field study in Guangdong Province, this paper describes the social media use of Chinese migrant workers in the manufacturing sector. It was found that social media plays a significant role in the lives of young workers who have left their rural hometowns in early adulthood and struggle to survive in the urban centers. They buy expensive IT devices to gain a social reputation, as social media provides opportunities for self-expression; strengthens their self-consciousness; and to a certain extent, influences their world view. For most of the workers in our study, social media has become a very important part of leisure time and entertainment. Moreover, the life in virtual worlds provides them a psychological compensation mechanism to temporarily avoid the pressure of their daily lives.

column3: Digital Mobilization in Disaster Response: The Work & Self-Organization of On-Line Pet Advocates in Response to Hurricane Sandy
column9: Joanne White, Leysia Palen, Kenneth Anderson
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: This ethnographic study of a Facebook Page founded on 28 October 2012 in anticipation of Hurricane Sandy’s US landfall reveals how on-line pet advocates--a large but loosely organized social movement--mobilized their ad hoc discretionary activities to more cooperative, organized work to assist numerous displaced pets. The investigation shows how innovations around “crossposting” to create a more persistent form of visual data management were important. It describes how these innnovations produced an improvised case management system around which members of the pet-advocacy crowd could collectively work to help displaced pets. The paper connects to the CSCW and organizational science literature to consider how this emergent community articulated work and structured the mission of the Page.

column3: Twitter as a Navigator for Stranded Commuters during the Great East Japan Earthquake
column9: Hiroko Wilensky
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: During the evening of the Great East Japan Earthquake on March 11, 2011, the Japan Railroad and other railroad systems ceased their operations. This left more than five million commuters stranded in the metropolitan Tokyo area. Many commuters walked hours to return home, while others struggled to find temporary shelter and stayed overnight in the city. The increased use of social media, such as Twitter, was widely reported on Japanese media after the Great East Japan Earthquake. This study is a qualitative investigation of the use of Twitter by the stranded commuters and their supporters in the great Tokyo area immediately after the earthquake. This paper describes the possibilities and problems of Twitter use under a rapidly changing disaster situation and examines if Twitter was an effective navigator for helping stranded commuters return home or find shelter.

column3: Deep Twitter Diving: Exploring Topical Groups in Microblogs at Scale
column9: Parantapa Bhattacharya, Saptarshi Ghosh, Juhi Kulshrestha, Mainack Mondal, Muhammad Bilal Zafar, Niloy Ganguly, Krishna Gummadi
column33: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column42: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column51: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column69: Max Planck Institute of Software Systems
column100: Social network analysis; Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: We present a semantic methodology to identify topical groups in Twitter on a large variety of topics, each consisting of users who are experts on or interested in a specific topic. Early studies investigating the nature of Twitter, suggest that it is a social media platform consisting of a relatively small section of elite users, producing information on few popular topics such as media, politics, and music, and the general population consuming it. We show that this narration ignores a rich set of highly specialized topics, ranging from geology, neurology, to astrophysics and karate, being discussed by their own topical groups. We present a detailed characterization of these topical groups based on their network structures and tweeting behaviors. Analyzing these groups on the backdrop of the common identity and bond theory in social sciences, shows that these groups exhibit characteristics of topical identity based groups, rather than social bond based ones.

column3: Smart Face: Enhancing Creativity During Video Conferences using Real-time Facial Deformation
column9: Naoto Nakazato, Shigeo Yoshida, Sho Sakurai, Takuji Narumi, Tomohiro Tanikawa, Michitaka Hirose
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User experience/interaction design; Telepresence/video/desktop conferencing
column101: This study develops a method for improving creativity by changing the facial appearance of people during video conferences. We focus on enhancing creativity during human interactions, especially cooperative work situations such as video conferences. Psychological studies have revealed that the facial appearance of people can affect creativity, i.e., “emotion can affect creativity” and “the appearance of others can affect the emotions.” Based on the knowledge, we hypothesized that the media technology which modifies the facial appearance of people appropriately can enhance our creativity during cooperative work. Therefore, we develop a method to affect creativity by changing the facial appearance in real-time, such as facial expressions and facial resemblance. We test the effectiveness of this method by building a system for collaborative video conferences. The user study show that the proposed method could enhance creativity.

column3: Ensemble: Exploring Complementary Strengths of Leaders and Crowds in Creative Collaboration
column9: Joy Kim, Justin Cheng, Michael Bernstein
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Crowdsourcing
column101: In story writing, the diverse perspectives of the crowd could support an author’s search for the perfect character, setting, or plot. However, structuring crowd collaboration is challenging. Too little structure leads to unfocused, sprawling narratives, and too much structure stifles creativity. Motivated by the idea that individual creative leaders and the crowd have complementary creative strengths, we present an approach where a leader directs the high-level vision for a story and articulates creative constraints for the crowd. This approach is embodied in Ensemble, a novel collaborative story-writing platform. In a month-long short story competition, over one hundred volunteer users on the web started over fifty short stories using Ensemble. Leaders used the platform to direct collaborator work by establishing creative goals, and collaborators contributed meaningful, high-level ideas to stories through specific suggestions. This work suggests that asymmetric creative contributions may support a broad new class of creative collaborations.

column3: Duography in The Classroom: Collaborative Creative Engagement by Two-sided Mobile Phone Photography
column9: Florian Güldenpfennig, Wolfgang Reitberger, Eva Ganglbauer, Geraldine Fitzpatrick
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: The potential of mobile handheld devices to support collaborative mobile learning has been explored for some time however little attention has been paid to arts education. Further new features of mobile phones such as dual cameras open new possibilities for supporting collaborative learning. In this paper, we investigate a novel kind of ‘two-sided’ photography, which we call ‘duography’ for mobile phones in the educational setting of an art class. The study involves 17 adolescents (16-18 years old) working in groups, and their art teacher, over the course of 12 weeks. We analyse a resulting rich set of ‘two-sided photos’ to unpack the potential of this novel kind of photography for art education with technology-mediated cooperative artefacts. Thereby we illustrate how duography can mediate collaborative creative engagement during the process of art creation by fostering teamwork as well as after the creation by reflective group discussions.

column3: Collaboration, Coordination and Control: System Development and Bureaucratic Authority in the Thai Public Sector
column9: Radaphat Chongthammakun, Steven Jackson
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: New collaborative infrastructures in public sector organizations have been widely cited for their contributions to efficiency, improved service delivery, enhanced cross-agency collaboration, and bureaucratic innovation. But they have also had important and often overlooked effects on relations of organizational authority and control. This paper examines the background, process, and outcome of three recent cases of computerized collaboration support tools in the Thai public sector. We find that such systems have encountered three main tensions that shape and limit their impact: tensions between competing demands for centralization and autonomy; tensions between official procedures and the informal practices by which bureaucratic work is accomplished; and tensions stemming from the workarounds, duplications, and system proliferations accompanying efforts at standardization. We argue that investments in new computational infrastructures predicated on collaboration and coordination must be simultaneously understood as complex interventions into the basic relations of control that structure and coordinate power and authority in large bureaucratic organizations.

column3: MyPosition: The Impact of an Interactive Poll Visualization on Public Civic Participation
column9: Nina Valkanova, Robert Walter, Andrew Vande Moere, Jörg Müller
column23: Quality and Usability Lab Telekom Innovation Laboratories
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; User experience/interaction design
column101: We present the design and evaluation of MyPosition, a public display in the form of a large projection, featuring an interactive poll visualization. MyPosition aims at facilitating the deliberation and comparison of individual opinions on locally relevant topics in an opportunistic and engaging way. We evaluated MyPosition in an in-the-wild study and demonstrated that the public and engaging nature of the installation was effective in enticing participation and discussion. We found that (i) the increased identifiability of voters positively impacted the engagement with and the social debate around the installation, however lowered the actual voting rate; (ii) people submitted their personal opinion instead of playing around with the interactive features; and (iii) the display led to considerable discussion as well as nudging among people, in particular in zones beyond the interaction area in front of the screen.   \

column3: Enhancing Community Awareness and Participation to  Local Heritage with an Mobile Application
column9: Kyungsik (Keith) Han, Patrick Shih, Mary Beth Rosson, John Carroll
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: One goal of local communities is to create and reinforce community identity by connecting residents to their local heritage. Technologies have enabled and facilitated the creation and consumption of digitized history content provided by official history institutions as well as individuals. Although much research has been conducted to understand technical and social aspects of digital cultural heritage, little empirical research has investigated how people perceive, experience, and interact with community content that is socially generated and tied to locations, particularly with respect to building community heritage. To address this, we developed a mobile application called LSC (anonymized) and conducted a user study with 34 participants. The study results indicate that meaningful historic places evoked special attention from the participants, and that those who have lived in the community longer tended to contribute more to the community heritage effort. Participants utilized social features as a way of learning local history, reflecting personal experiences and stories, and co-creating rich layers of local history information from their perspectives.

column3: Are you still with me? Interaction Involvement in Dyadic Instant Messaging Conversations
column9: Duyen Nguyen, Susan Fussell
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Distributed/virtual teams
column101: This paper explores how participants express and interpret verbal cues of interaction involvement in dyadic conversations via text-based Instant Messaging (IM). We report an experimental study in which we manipulated the participants’ level of involvement using a distraction task. We found that interaction involvement had a positive effect on cognitive and affective processes such as mutual understanding, emotions, and satisfaction of computer-mediated conversations. Moreover, certain verbal cues such as the use of personal pronouns, assent words, cognitive mechanism words, and definite articles were a significant indication of the participants’ level of involvement in an IM conversation. We conclude with our suggestions for improving team collaboration using computer-mediated communication (CMC) tools.

column3: Sketching Awareness: A Participatory Study to Elicit Designs for Supporting Emergency Medical Teamwork
column9: Diana Kusunoki, Aleksandra Sarcevic, Zhan Zhang, Maria Yala
column100: Medical and health support; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
column101: Prior CSCW research on awareness in clinical settings has mostly focused on higher-level coordination at the inter-team, department, and inter-department levels. In this paper, we offer a perspective on what awareness means within the context of a setting that is different from what has been previously described by looking at collocated ad hoc teams treating critically ill patients with urgent needs. We report findings from four participatory design workshops conducted with emergency medicine clinicians at two regional emergency departments. Workshops were developed to elicit design ideas for information displays that support awareness in emergency medical situations. Through analysis of discussions and clinicians’ sketches of information displays, we identified five features of teamwork that can be used as a foundation for supporting awareness from the perspective of clinicians. Based on these findings, we contribute rich descriptions of four facets of awareness that teams manage during emergency medical situations and discuss them in relation to awareness facets found in the CSCW literature.

column3: Privacy Practices in Collaborative Environments: A Study of Emergency Department Staff
column9: Alison Murphy, Madhu Reddy, Heng Xu
column14: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column32: College of Information Sciences and Technology
column100: Privacy/access control/trust; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Medical and health support
column101: Privacy research has long focused on the individual. Yet most organizations are highly collaborative where teamwork is the norm. To examine privacy practices in collaborative settings, we conducted an ethnographic study of a highly collaborative and information-intensive setting – an emergency department (ED). We found that ED staff work practices did not always align with the organization’s privacy policies and procedures. We then discuss the use of workarounds when privacy policies interfere with work practices, the challenge of assigning accountability for enforcing privacy in collaborative environments, and implications for technical and policy design. We conclude with some thoughts on the future of privacy research in collaborative settings.

column3: Standing on the Schemas of Giants: Socially Augmented Information Foraging
column9: Aniket Kittur, Andrew Peters, Abdigani Diriye
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Collaborative information retrieval
column101: People spend an enormous amount of time searching for complex information online; for example, consumers researching new purchases or patients learning about their conditions. As they search, people build up rich mental schemas about their target domains; which, if effectively shared, could accelerate learning for others with similar interests. In this paper we introduce a novel approach for integrating the schemas individuals develop as they gather information online and surfacing them for others with similar interests. Through a controlled experiment we show that having access to the others’ schemas while foraging for information helps new users to induce more useful, prototypical, and better-structured schemas than gathering information alone.

column3: Checking In and Hanging Out: A Social Approach to Fitness Interventions for Adolescents
column9: Andrew Miller, Jessica Pater, Elizabeth Mynatt
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Mobile and embedded devices; Medical and health support
column101: Social fitness interventions for adolescents have the potential to improve adolescents’ attitudes and perceptions about fitness through peer influence and interpersonal accountability. However, prior work focuses on competitive design features, and prior systems have been designed for small groups or large-scale competitions. We present our own system, StepStream, a pedometer-based microblog we designed and deployed over four weeks with 42 US middle school students. StepStream users improved their attitudes and perceptions about fitness and increased their sense of social support for fitness. We describe how our system is informed by social theories of health behavior change, moves beyond small groups without requiring direct competition, and encourages adolescents to blend fitness into their offline experience. Our investigation offers an additional set of theory-based design approaches for youth-focused social health systems, and expands our understanding of the potential for social computing systems to positively impact health behaviors.

column3: A Case Study of Organizing for Geographically Distributed Work Using Social Media
column9: Aditya Johri, Hon Jie Teo
column23: Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Virginia, United States
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Computer-Mediated Communication; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: We present findings from a case study of an innovative firm that successfully leveraged social media by design to work in a highly geographically distributed manner. We synthesize five enabling mechanisms used by the firm: (1) aligning use of social media and distributed work practices from firm inception; (2) utilizing a media ecology to support diverse needs and functions across locations (3) creating hiring practices that appropriately socialized newcomers into social media and distributed work practices at the firm; (4) supporting continuous tailoring and adaptability of social media for supporting distributed work; and, (5) aligning social media use with firm’s product development to enable continuous distributed innovation. This study provides a unique insight into distributed organizing, a work structure whose effectiveness continues to be debated, by illustrating how distributed work can be effectively structured using social media. We discuss implications for theory and practice.

column3: Streaming on Twitch: Shared Experiences of Play Catalyze Intimate Communities
column9: William Hamilton, Oliver Garretson, Andruid Kerne
column15: Interface Ecology Lab @ Texas A&M University
column33: Interface Ecology Lab, Texas A&M University
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Entertainment/games; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Previously, video streaming sites have remained at the fringes of online social media. In the past 2 years, video gaming live streams on sites like Twitch.tv have developed larger viewerships and more truly social media. In conjunction with gameplay, participant interaction gains emphasis. In this paper, we present ethnographic investigation of live streaming of video games on Twitch. \  \ We found that streamers and viewers frequently share their personal lives and form intimate relationships through pro- longed interaction, leading to the formation of open, yet close- knit communities around streams. However, as the popularity of particular streams and streamers reaches a threshold of scale, breakdowns emerge in the fabric of meaningful social experience. We discuss emergent problems and collectively developed stopgap solutions for supporting real-time commu- nication and managing anti-social behavior at large scales. Finally, we present implications for design that must be ad- dressed for live streaming to continue to grow and preserve the intimate social experiences that are its hallmarks.

column3: Books as a Social Technology
column9: Annika Hupfeld, Tom Rodden
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: E-books are becoming ubiquitous. Whether or not they will eventually replace books or merely complement them, there is a concern that something important might be lost in moving from print to digital books. While there is a wealth of research into the challenges and opportunities of e-reading, there is little research aiming to understand the broader role of books in everyday life. Rather than speculating on what books are in the digital age, in this paper, we wish to ask what books do. To do so, we conducted a series of in-depth interviews with ten UK households to understand everyday uses of books. Our findings suggest that books are not merely reading technologies but a resource for everyday social and personal engagements. We discuss implications of re-framing books as social technologies for the design of e-books.

column3: Green Dolphin: Crowd-sourcing the Task of Answering Student Questions
column9: Chulakorn Aritajati, N. Hari Narayanan
column14: Intelligent and Interactive Systems Laboratory Computer Science & Software Engineering Department
column23: Intelligent and Interactive Systems Laboratory Computer Science & Software Engineering Department
column100: E-Learning and Education; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User experience/interaction design; Crowdsourcing
column101: We present the design of an educational question and answer system, Green Dolphin, and describe a study of its usage in a graduate Computer Science course. Question and answer boards are quite popular on the web. A system called Piazza is in widespread use in the educational domain. One benefit of such a system is that students receive quick responses to their questions from peers. However, seeing instructors’ answers may discourage students from contributing. We implemented a delay in the publication of instructors' answers to encourage student participation. We also implemented a technique to automatically identify "expert" students from their question asking and answering behaviors, and a point-based reward system. We evaluated Green Dolphin in a course and compared its usage with that of Piazza. We found that delaying instructor answers increased students’ participation, the reward system motivated students, and students felt pride in being identified by Green Dolphin as an expert.

column3: Understanding Workforce Chatter with Enterprise Social Pulse
column9: N. Sadat Shami, Jiang Yang, Casey Dugan, Tristan Ratchford, Jamie Rasmussen, Todd Soule, Werner Geyer, Ido Guy, Laura Panc, Yannick Assogba
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: Social media has the potential to augment traditional surveys in understanding the opinions and sentiment of employees. In this paper, we introduce Enterprise Social Pulse (ESP) – a tool designed to support analysts whose job involves understanding employee chatter. ESP aggregates and analyzes data from internal and external social media sources while respecting employee privacy. It surfaces the data through a user interface that supports organic results and keyword search, data segmentation and filtering, and several analytics and visualization features. An evaluation of ESP was conducted with 19 Human Resources professionals. Results from a survey and interviews with participants revealed the value and willingness to use ESP, but also surfaced challenges around deploying an employee social media listening solution in an organization.

column3: Phones and Flu Shots:  Phone Separation Can Activate Attachment Behavior
column9: Stephanie Friedman, Jeff Hancock
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Mobile and embedded devices
column101: Given how much time people spend with their mobile phone, is it possible for people to form an emotional attachment to their device? To test this question the present study separated people from their phone while they waited for a flu shot, a potentially anxiety-producing event. According to attachment theory, phone attached individuals should experience separation distress and rate the upcoming flu shot as more painful than unattached individuals. The results supported this prediction: high phone attachment individuals anticipated more pain than low phone attachment individuals when separated from their phone. We also found that high phone attachment individuals were more likely to be younger and to own a smartphone than a regular phone; we found no difference between genders. Our results extend self-reported perceptions of phone attachment by demonstrating that phone separation can activate key attachment behaviors, such as separation distress.

column3: From Rookie to All-Star: Professional Development in a Graphic Design Social Networking Site
column9: Jennifer Marlow, Laura Dabbish
column24: HCII & Heinz College, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use
column101: A plethora of domain-focused social networking sites have emerged and have the potential to change the nature of work as we know it. These sites are dedicated to specific professional activities and are being used both for learning and gaining employment. Little work to date has examined how individuals use social network functionality for professional development in these types of communities. We present a qualitative investigation into how SNS functionality supports two important components of professional activity: skill development and reputation building. We focus on activity within Dribbble, a social network site for graphic designers. Through a series of interviews with novice and experienced Dribbble users who work within and outside of traditional organizations, we identified ways they leverage SNS features for learning and skill development. We find that benefits of the site are dependent on extensive social capital development activities in order to garner attention for posted work. Our results inform the design of online social settings for professional development.

column3: Institutional Logics of the EMR and the Problem of ‘Perfect’ but Inaccurate Accounts
column9: Kathleen Pine, Melissa Mazmanian
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Medical and health support; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: EMR promise to simultaneously enhance coordination and provide transparency and accountability in work process. In this paper we use empirical data to explore how this promise plays out in the everyday tasks of clinicians. Building on CSCW literature that suggests that the accounting functions of EMR are impinging on coordination of work, we draw on new institutionalism to outline how certain institutional logics around safety are shaping experiences of EMR in-situ. We suggest that institutionalized logics of U.S. healthcare are embedded in the EMR design itself, structuring how “safety” is achieved and evaluated. Using over one year of ethnographic research in an obstetrical unit, we find that the institutional logics of “safety” embedded in the EMR create negative organizational outcomes, undermining coordination and necessitating inaccurate accounts of work. We provide design implications to address these issues in the current institutional environment and envision how systems might be designed to promote alternate logics of safety that are social, dynamic, and cast humans as expert agents.

column3: Crowd Synthesis: Extracting Categories and Clusters from Complex Data
column9: Paul André, Aniket Kittur, Steven Dow
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Analysts synthesize complex, qualitative data to uncover themes and concepts, but the process is time-consuming, cognitively taxing, and automated techniques show mixed success. Crowdsourcing could help this process through on-demand harnessing of flexible and powerful human cognition, but incurs other challenges including limited attention and expertise. Further, text data can be complex, high-dimensional, and ill-structured. We address two major challenges unsolved in prior crowd clustering work: scaffolding expertise for novice crowd workers, and creating consistent and accurate categories when each worker only sees a small portion of the data. To address these challenges we present an empirical study of a two-stage approach to enable crowds to create an accurate and useful overview of a dataset: A) we draw on cognitive theory to assess how re-representing data can shorten and focus on salient dimensions; and B) introduce an iterative clustering approach that provides workers a global overview of data. We demonstrate a classification-plus-context approach elicits the most accurate categories at the most useful level of abstraction.

column3: Social Data Analysis via Commenting on a Visualization-Oriented News Blog
column9: Jessica Hullman, Nicholas Diakopoulos, Eytan Adar
column15: University of Michigan School of Information
column100: Collaborative visualization; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Recommender and Filtering Systems
column101: Publishing visualizations is a trend in non-academic outlets like news sites. Discussion and social engagement through online commenting can facilitate collaborative analysis of visual data. Yet much remains to be understood about how people make sense of online data visualization through interactive commenting outside of research prototypes. We present a detailed study of commenting activity around visualizations published on a mainstream news outlet, The Economist’s Graphic Detail blog. We contribute insights into behavior around five different referential anchors to which comments are frequently directed. These results inform the development of an automated classifier that can coarsely yet effectively differentiate comments referencing different types of anchors with an accuracy of 84.8%. We conclude with a discussion of the implications of the results for understanding and organizing online commentary, including as input to the design process.

column3: Technology-Based Family Communication Routines Within and Between Rural and Urban Kenya
column9: Erick Oduor, Carman Neustaedter, Tejinder Judge, Kate Hennessy, Serena Hillman, Carolyn Pang
column41: School of Interactive Arts and Technology
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: Little research has explored how families communicate in countries where technology availability and infrastructure are limited. Rural-urban migration is shifting modes of connecting people in such regions and there are large variances in education and income levels. This presents challenges for technology adoption and use.  The goal of our research was to explore the technology-based communication routines of families in rural and urban areas of Kenya, Africa, such that we could better understand how to design technology that is specific to this region’s cultural practices and socio-economic context. Results from an exploratory study show that Kenyans had distinct social protocols and routines for exchanging information, timing communication, and being available for mobile phone calls. We also found that practices were specific to urban vs. rural regions and communicating between the two areas caused challenges.  These results contribute to a growing acknowledgement of the complexity of the ‘digital divide’ and present challenges for the design of family communication technologies for Kenyans.

column3: Editing Beyond Articles: Diversity & Dynamics of Teamwork in Open Collaborations
column9: Jonathan Morgan, Michael Gilbert, David McDonald, Mark Zachry
column100: Distributed/virtual teams; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: We report a study of Wikipedia in which we use a mixed-methods approach to understand how participation in specialized workgroups called WikiProjects has changed over the life of the encyclopedia. While previous work has analyzed the work of WikiProjects in supporting the development of articles within particular subject domains, the collaborative role of WikiProjects that do not fit this conventional mold has not been empirically examined. We combine content analysis, interviews and analysis of edit logs to identify and characterize these alternative WikiProjects and the work they do. Our findings suggest that WikiProject participation reflects community concerns and shifts in the community’s conception of valued work over the past six years. We discuss implications for other open collaborations that need flexible, adaptable coordination mechanisms to support a range of content creation, curation and community maintenance tasks.

column3: Sounds of Silence: Exploring Contributions to Conversa-tions, Non-Responses and the Impact of Mediating Tech-nologies in Triple Space
column9: Joon Suk Lee, Deborah Tatar
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: We investigate collocated triads as they play a collaborative, problem-solving game using distributed technology on laptops. We examine how different triads attain and maintain mutual understanding in triple-space––when working on a hard problem, with communicating technologies and face-to-face interaction. We present qualitative and quantitative evidence that demonstrates the descriptive adequacy of a model of triadic interaction in triple space. We use that model to argue that the notion of good-enoughness is not a group attribute, but rather tied to each dyadic pair. This intellectual framework allows us to examine how non-response operates within these triple-space interactions when interaction is supported by different media.   The results related to non-response raise the possibility that different media may result in subtle changes influences on the balance of participant goals.

column3: Negotiating communication availability: Agreeing how to communicate across contexts
column9: John Tang, Henry Chen
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: While presence and awareness among remote collaborators have been research topics for over 20 years, the current landscape of diverse communication tools and mobile devices creates some new challenges for negotiating availability. We interviewed 26 people about their current practices in negotiating availability among at least moderately close contacts across work, home, and mobile contexts. We found distinct differences in how people managed their availability for work compared to personal contacts. At work, people typically used the communication tool that was in shared use (usually an IM system). For personal contacts, people chose to explicitly negotiate their availability through lightweight exchanges enabled by mobile texting. We identify the reasons for these differences, and discuss implications for design and further research.

column3: You’re Happy, I’m Happy: Diffusion of Mood Expression on Twitter
column9: Munmun De Choudhury
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation
column101: We study the propagation of expression of moods from one individual to another in social media. Specifically, we utilize an ensemble of more than 200 moods, and follow their trails of retweets on Twitter. We examine the diffusion of these moods through the characteristics of the author of the retweeted post, of the post, and its linguistic style and topical content. We observe that moods of high valence and low to moderate activation propagate the most. Our findings also indicate that mood-bearing posts from individuals of medium #followers show highest diffusion, instead of elite users. Further, moods in postings with high self-attentional focus, posted by socially interactive women, and with fewer links diffuse the most. Finally, we leverage these characteristics to build a linear regression model that can predict extent of diffusion in a mood-bearing post. The model yields accuracy of 75% showing that user’s attributes as well as post’s language characteristics are key factors driving the diffusion of moods in social media.

column3: The Language that Gets People to Give: Phrases that Predict Success on Kickstarter
column9: Tanushree Mitra, Eric Gilbert
column100: Crowdsourcing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: Crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter—where entrepreneurs and artists look to the internet for funding—have quickly risen to prominence. However, we know very little about the factors driving the “crowd” to take projects to their funding goal. In this paper we explore the factors which lead to successfully funding a crowdfunding project. We study a corpus of 45K crowdfunded projects, analyzing 9M phrases and 59 other variables commonly present on crowdfunding sites. The language used in the project has surprising predictive power—accounting for 58.56% of the variance around successful funding. A closer look at the phrases shows they exhibit general persuasion principles. For example, also receive two reflects the principle of Reciprocity and is a top predictor of successful funding. We conclude this paper by announcing the release of the predictive phrases and the control variables as a public dataset, hoping that our work can enable new features on crowdfunding sites—tools to help both backers and project creators make the best use of their time and money.

column3: Using Expertise Scores to Motivate Expertise Building in the Enterprise
column9: Mercan Topkara, Justin Weisz, Shimei Pan, Jie Lu, Jennifer Lai
column100: Organization/office/workplace support; E-Learning and Education; User experience/interaction design
column101: Expertise and skill assessments are a common aspect of working in an enterprise, but manual assessments are onerous and quickly out-of-date while automated assessments can be inaccurate. We explore two dimensions associated with reporting automated expertise assessments to users: the inclusion of social comparison and GUI presentation of either a precise score or a range for the score (i.e. 35% vs 30 – 40%). In a controlled experiment (N=60), we examined the impact of these dimensions on the perceived accuracy of the assessments, perceived utility of and engagement with the social expertise building system, and willingness to share expertise scores within the enterprise. Our findings indicate that the presence of social comparison increased perception of system utility as well as levels of engagement with the system. Precise scores tended to increase trust of the assessment. Participants indicated they were willing to share their scores if asked by others or if a culture of sharing existed in the organization.

column3: Design-Researcher as Therapist: The unexpected implications of discursive methods in CSCW
column9: Stacy Branham, Steve Harrison
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: The evolving philosophies, methods, and designed artifacts of the CSCW design researcher are more collaborative and value-active than ever before. It is not uncommon, for example, for researcher and participant to co-construct design solutions, share intimate life stories over design probes, or seek personal fulfillment through reflective technologies. We argue that discourses opened by design research can constitute a sort of therapeutic communication. That is, they have the potential to shape selfhood and refigure participants’ most deeply felt relational bonds, for better or worse, in small ways or large. In this paper, we unpack the notion of therapeutic communication through engaging multiple literatures and findings from our study of intimate couple relationships. We conclude by exploring ethical dilemmas presented when we appreciate that the same activities we use in making knowledge and making technology are also in service of making (inter)personal identities. \

column3: Modeling Search Processes using Hidden States in Collaborative Exploratory Web Search
column9: Zhen Yue, Shuguang Han, Daqing He
column100: Collaborative information retrieval; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User experience/interaction design
column101: It has been rare to investigate search processes that involve complex interactions, such as collaborative search process. Previous approaches of applying individual search process models directly into collaborative setting have also be identified as problematic. In this paper, we proposed an innovative approach to model collaborative search process using Hidden Markov Model (HMM), which is an automatic technique for analyzing temporal sequential data. Obtained through a user study, the data used in this paper consist of two different tasks in both collaborative exploratory Web search and individual exploratory Web search conditions. Our results show that the identified hidden patterns of search process through HMM are compatible with previous well-known models. Besides, HMM has the benefit of providing more details than previous models. It generates richer and more detailed information on search process, which was demonstrated in our study to be useful for analyzing task differences and the correlation of search process with search performance.

column3: How Social Q&A Sites are Changing Knowledge Sharing in Open Source Software Communities
column9: Bogdan Vasilescu, Alexander Serebrenik, Prem Devanbu, Vladimir Filkov
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Collaborative software development; Crowdsourcing
column101: Mailing lists have been the preferred means for coordinating development and user support activities in open source software development. With the emergence and popularity growth of social Q&A platforms such as StackExchange, this is beginning to change. Such platforms offer different socio-technical incentives to their participants than mailing lists do, e.g., rich web environments to store and manage content collaboratively, or a place to showcase their expertise more visibly to potential recruiters. However, one of the fundamental differences between StackExchange and mailing lists is gamification, i.e., participants compete to obtain reputation points and badges. Using a case study of R, a popular data analysis software, we investigate how mailing list participation has evolved since the launch of StackExchange. We found that mailing list experts are migrating to StackExchange, and their behavior is influenced by gamification: participants active on both are more active and provide faster answers on StackExchange than on the mailing list, suggesting they are motivated by the game.

column3: How Players Value their Characters in World of Warcraft
column9: Carl Gutwin, Ian Livingston, Regan Mandryk, Max Birk
column100: Virtual Worlds/Avatars/Proxies; User experience/interaction design; Entertainment/games
column101: Characters in games such as World of Warcraft allow players to act in the game world and to interact with others. Game characters and avatars are a mediated form of self-representation for the player, but some research suggests that players also view characters in other ways that have to do with the kinds of value that the characters provide. To better understand the ways that players value their characters in an online environment, we carried out a semi-structured interview study of twenty World of Warcraft players. From our data we identify ten kinds of value that characters can provide – including utility, investment, communication, memory, enjoyment, and representations of relationships, as well as value as an opportunity for experience, creativity, sociability, and self-expression. The analytical lens of value provides a new understanding of the ways that players appreciate characters in online multi-user worlds. Our results can help developers understand and enhance an element of multi-player games that contributes greatly to player experience and satisfaction.

column3: “Maybe It Was a Joke” - Emotion Rating in Text-Based Communication by Non-Native English Speakers
column9: Ari Hautasaari, Naomi Yamashita
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Cross-cultural Systems or Studies
column101: Recent literature has largely disproven the notion that emotions cannot be effectively conveyed in text-only media. However, whether non-native speakers can accurately detect emotions in text-based communication has not yet been addressed. This paper introduces an experiment where native English-speakers (NS) and Japanese non-native English speakers (NNS) rate the emotional tone of real text-based messages written by native English speaking authors. NNS were less accurate at detecting the emotions in messages compared to NS. NNS accuracy improved when the English messages were long but reduced when replies to the original messages were included as additional contextual information. While NS relied heavily on contextual cues such as emoticons to determine the emotional tone of a message, NNS relied on a wider range of words overall to determine the emotional tone of each message. The results are used to inform the design of supporting tools for multilingual communication and intercultural collaboration.

column3: Being A Turker
column9: David Martin, Jacki O'Neill, Benjamin Hanrahan, Neha Gupta
column100: Crowdsourcing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Crowdsourcing is a key current topic in CSCW. We build upon findings of a few qualitative studies of crowdworkers. We conducted a virtual ethnography of Turker Nation, a general forum for Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) users. Using forum data we provide novel depth and detail on how the Turker Nation members operate as economic actors, working out which Requesters and jobs are worthwhile to them. We show some of key the ways Turker Nation functions as a community and also look further into Turker-Requester relationships from the Turker perspective – considering practical, emotional and moral aspects. Finally, we analyse Turking as a form of invisible work. We do this to illustrate practical and ethical issues relating to working with Turkers and AMT, and to promote design directions to support Turkers and their relationships with Requesters.

column3: Understanding Valued Contribution Types in Open Source Design Discussions
column9: Roshanak Zilouchian Moghaddam, Mohsen Vakilian, Brian Bailey, Wai-Tat Fu
column100: Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Collaborative software development; Studies of Wikipedia/Web
column101: Open source software is a community effort but not all contribution types are valued equally. In this paper, we report the results of a mixed-methods study aimed at understanding valued contribution types and examining whether contributor roles (designer vs. developer) and seniority (senior vs. junior) affect how contributions are valued. The study was conducted in context of a popular open source content management system. Through interviews, we identified different types of contributions and perceptions of how these contributions are valued. We then quantified how contributions are valued based on analyzing exchanges of acknowledgment in the discussions. Our analysis revealed that valued contributions are beyond software development and include social support and collaborations. We also found that senior members more often value different contribution types than junior members. Finally, our analysis indicates that designer contributions are valued less often than developer contributions. Based on our results, we formulated implications for open source communities that want to improve the sense of contribution among members with different roles.

column3: Think Globally, Act Locally: A Case Study of a Free Food Sharing Community and Social Networking
column9: Eva Ganglbauer, Geraldine Fitzpatrick, Ozge Subasi, Florian Güldenpfennig
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social network analysis; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: Social networking has a long history of supporting communities online. In this paper we are concerned with a specific community that has formed around free food sharing to save food from being wasted. Specifically, Foodsharing.de is a platform that enables consumers, farmers, organizations and retailers to offer and collect food. Associated with this is the Foodsharing Facebook group where broader community discussions take place. We report on a qualitative analysis of the Foodsharing Facebook group to understand its role in emerging and sustaining the community. The Facebook group is a place where the individual values and motives, socio-political discussions and mass media interrelate and create new social patterns through narratives and local community building. We present our findings as interplay between individual, community, organisational levels, public relations and media, the operational platform Foodsharing.de that enables local communities and the Facebook group where global ideological framing of the community takes place.

column3: Predicting the Future with a Social Network
column9: Clifton Forlines, Sarah Miller, Leslie Guelcher, Robert Bruzzi
column100: Crowdsourcing
column101: Researchers have long known that aggregate estimations \ built from the individual opinions of a large group of people \ often outperform the estimations of individual experts. This \ phenomenon is generally described as the Wisdom of \ Crowds. In respect to forecasting future events, this \ approach has shown promise. Previous research has \ demonstrated the value of utilizing meta-forecasts \ (forecasts about what others in the group will predict) when \ aggregating. In this paper, we describe an extension to \ meta-forecasting and demonstrate the value of modeling the \ familiarity among a population’s members (its social \ network) and applying this model to forecast aggregation. \ A pair of studies demonstrates the value of taking this \ model into account, and the described technique produces \ aggregate forecast for future events that are significantly \ better than the standard Wisdom of Crowds approach.

column3: Framework for Designing Social Support Systems for Illness Management
column9: Jina Huh, Andrea Hartzler, David McDonald, Wanda Pratt
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User experience/interaction design; Home/family/intimacy support; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Medical and health support
column101: Social support plays a critical factor in aiding patients’ illness management. Social support technologies—such as online health communities, blogs, and chatting systems—have become widely available for patients with various illnesses. However, patients’ needs and preferences for social support differ depending on the characteristics of individuals and the illness context. In this paper, we present the social support design framework, which guides social support system development based on needs associated with different illness contexts. We describe in detail the formulation process of the framework using two underlying models—the taxonomy of disease management and the CSCW Time/space model—to aid our understanding of specialized needs around social support and the mapping of those needs to existing CSCW systems. We discuss the potential for our framework to help people design systems that address patients’ social support needs. We further discuss how others can use the framework to illuminate design thinking and research.

column3: Account Sharing in the Context of Networked Hospitality Exchange
column9: Airi Lampinen, Airi Lampinen, Airi Lampinen
column24: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT / Aalto University
column100: Studies of Wikipedia/Web; Social Networking Site Design and Use; Home/family/intimacy support
column101: This paper examines account sharing in the context of networked hospitality exchange. I discuss the dynamics of account sharing based on a qualitative interview study with multi-person households who offer to host visitors via Couchsurfing.org. Findings reveal that multi-people households that engage in account sharing face several challenges, including presenting multiple people in one profile, coordinating negotiations over access to domestic space, and representing in a fair way the reputation hosts have accumulated together over time. Amidst the rising rhetoric of a ‘reputation economy’, this paper calls for engaging the inclusions, exclusions, and inequalities that reputation metrics may renew or create, especially if they fail to acknowledge people’s account sharing practices. Furthermore, this paper encourages adopting a design focus beyond individuals in order to cater to maintaining shared accounts and interacting with others through them. The findings have implications for a variety of hospitality exchange services and other online systems.

column3: Groupgarden: Supporting Brainstorming through a Metaphorical Group Mirror
column9: Sarah Tausch, Ismail Kosan, Doris Hausen, Heinrich Hussmann
column100: Collaborative visualization; Tabletop and Large Wall Displays; Other domain-specific support
column101: Creative group work is a common method for problem solving and idea generation. Brainstorming is one way to support idea generation in groups. To ensure the productivity of this creativity technique, participants have to observe several rules. Nevertheless, problems such as social loafing, free riding or evaluation apprehension can occur. Additionally, the amount of contributions of group members is often unbalanced. In this paper, we present an approach to support brainstorming rules and to diminish possible problems. We developed a metaphorical group mirror providing feedback about individual as well as group performance. In a user study, we compared brainstorming sessions supported by the feedback of Groupgarden with sessions without any additional support. Results show that the metaphorical group mirror does effectively support the adherence to particular brainstorming rules. Moreover, participation was more balanced while the total number of ideas did not decrease.

column3: Predicting If and When a Community Will Respond
column9: Jacob Bartel, Prasun Dewan
column100: Recommender and Filtering Systems; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
column101: In post-and-response systems, users often post hoping to receiving responses in a timely manner. Based on when a response will occur, users may want to wait, postpone their work, or perform alternate actions.  We have developed first-cut recommender algorithms that assist the users by predicting if and when a response will occur without assuming anything about the recipients. The main idea in this work is that the response rate of a post in a community thread is correlated with the response rates of previous posts in “similar” threads. To evaluate our work, we have used two public databases: the Newsgroup 20 and the Stack Exchange public data dumps. For Newsgroups (Stack Overflow), we achieved 75.3% (85.2%) accuracy when predicting whether a response will occur and less than 20% (80 %) error predicting the response time. Our results in both cases indicate that our approach, arguably, has practical value by giving a potential poster a sense of scale for response times.

column3: Make Your Programming Questions Be Answered Quickly: A Content Oriented Study to Technical Q&A Forum
column9: Yi Wang
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Computer-Mediated Communication
column101: Online programming forums enable programming knowledge sharing across organizational boundaries. Understanding how questions are asked and answered in forums will not only help developers to access the knowledge they need fast but bring important design implications. We report a study of Question and Answer (Q&A) process on MSDN’s Visual C# general forum. This study is content-oriented instead of conventional social network analysis to CQA communities. We identified eight topic categories through two-round card sorting. We also explored various content features’ influences to Q&A process. A qualitative analysis was performed to identify different life-cycle patterns of questions. These findings \ highlight the role of content features, and the interaction effects between them and forum phases. Based on these findings, we make a set of suggestions to information seekers on how to make their questions be answered faster, and derive implications for technical forums. To verify our findings, we also conducted a small replication to a Java technical forum and compared the results.

column3: House Rules: The Collaborative Nature of Policy in Domestic Networks
column9: Andy Crabtree, Tom Rodden, Peter Tolmie, Richard Mortier, Tom Lodge, Patrick Brundell, Nadia Pantidi
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Home/family/intimacy support; Other domain-specific support
column101: We draw on ethnographic studies to understand the collaborative nature of network policies or rules in domestic settings. We outline the technical nature of network policy in enterprise domains and how this contrasts with the social or collaborative nature of rules in everyday life. We then consider the deployment of network control and policy system interfaces in domestic settings, highlighting the ways in which household members collaboratively exploited these to support network governance. Our results suggest that an important feature of network policy in domestic contexts is that rules about network activity are shaped by and answerable to the moral reasoning that governs domestic life. This reframes our understanding of how rules are oriented to and used in the home and has significant implications for the design of home network policy systems.

column3: Document Classification and Visualization for the Support of Interdisciplinary Collaboration
column9: Lisa Miller, Susanne Still, Rich Gazan
column100: Machine Learning and Data Mining; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical
column101: We present a computer supported tool for cooperative work in interdisciplinary fields, which we applied to and tested within the area of astrobiology. \ Our document classification and visualization system is fully automated and data driven, based on unsupervised machine learning algorithms that make minimal \ assumptions about the data, and network visualization tools. It can extract information about collaborations from unstructured databases \ with no meta-data. A new feature selection algorithm was created that gives an indication how many words should be used in word-count based cluster analysis. \ We used our method to analyze a body of publications that were produced by researchers from NASA's \ Astrobiology Institute. Our analysis shows the utility of our method by revealing structure that can aid the planning of collaborative research. We presented this analysis \ as a cultural probe, and recorded reactions from researchers that clearly indicated the success of our method in aiding interdisciplinary research by helping scientists from \ different disciplines to work together.

column3: Sharing the Now:  Applying a Relational Lens to Mobile Facebook Use
column9: Irina Shklovski, Nis Bornoe, Louise Barkhuus, Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
column101: HCI research has explored mobile technologies to support social activity on the go to produce greater feelings of connectedness. Much of this has focused on different mobile devices, individual preferences and modes of use. Yet social activity and connectedness are about ongoing enactments of relationships across technologies. Here we introduce the relational approach as a way to include relationships in addition to individual preferences in the design and analysis of mobile communication technologies. We discuss three strategies people use to manage tensions in their relation-ships: selection, segmentation and integration. Our data show that use of social technologies can at times destabilize social relations and occasion relational tensions, forcing users to renegotiate how they enact these relationships.

column3: VidWiki: Enabling the Crowd to Improve the Legibility of Online Educational Videos
column9: Andrew Cross, Mydhili Bayyapunedi, Dilip Ravindran, Edward Cutrell, William Thies
column100: E-Learning and Education; Crowdsourcing
column101: Videos are becoming an increasingly popular medium for communicating information, especially for online education. While text-based information platforms like Wikipedia have benefitted enormously from crowdsourced contributions for the creation and improvement of content, the various limitations of video hinder the collaborative editing and improvement of educational videos. To address this issue, we present VidWiki, an online platform that enables students to iteratively improve the presentation quality and content of educational videos. Through the platform, users can improve the legibility of handwriting, correct errors, or translate text in videos by overlaying typeset content such as text, shapes, equations, or images. We conducted a small user study in which 13 novice users annotated and revised Khan Academy videos. Our results suggest that with only a small investment of time on the part of viewers, it may be possible to make meaningful improvements in online educational videos.

column3: Being Senior and ICT: a Study of the Adoption and Use of ICT among Seniors in China
column9: Yuling Sun, Xianghua Ding, Tun Lu, Ning Gu
column100: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Computer-Mediated Communication; Home/family/intimacy support; Other domain-specific support
column101: Existing work on seniors and ICT often focuses on seniors as a socially isolated group with physical and cognitive decline. However, this is only part of the story of being senior, and may only represent a view from non-seniors’ perspective, not seniors’. In this paper, drawing on a qualitative study of 17 seniors and their adoption and use of ICT in China, we uncover how seniors themselves address the question of what it means to be a senior, and how their self-identities and values help or hinder their adoption and use of ICT.  This work calls for a number sensitivities when design for seniors: sensitivity to seniors’ self-identities, sensitivity to seniors’ values, and sensitivity to senior’s social ecology.

column3: “You can’t block people offline”: Examining how Facebook’s affordances shape users’ disclosure process
column9: Jessica Vitak, Jinyoung Kim
column100: Social Networking Site Design and Use; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Privacy/access control/trust
column101: Guided by the underlying question of how—if at all—the self-disclosure process varies online, the present study explores the self-disclosure practices of 26 American graduate students on Facebook through in-depth interviews. Building on work by Derlega and Grzelak [13] on self-disclosure goals and focusing on the affordances of the site, findings reveal both commonalities with and extensions to existing communication research on self-disclosure, as users see both benefits and drawbacks to the high visibility and persistence of content shared through the site. Furthermore, users employed a wide spectrum of strategies to help them achieve their disclosure goals while decreasing perceived risks associated with making disclosures in a public forum. Importantly, these strategies generally sought to recreate the offline boundaries removed by the technical structure of the site and allow users to engage in a more strategic disclosure process with their network.

column3: Social Media Participation and Performance at Work: A Longitudinal Study
column9: N. Sadat Shami, Jeffrey Nichols
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The use of social media at work is gaining traction, and there is evidence to suggest that various benefits accrue from participating. Yet the relationship between using social media at work and employee performance has not been analyzed. Through a longitudinal study of 75,765 employees of a large global company over the course of 3 years, we find that some social media usage (number of forum posts, forum post length, and status update length) was predictive of performance, though at a small scale. This study provides initial empirical evidence that social media usage at work does not damage performance and may improve it.

column3: Transporting Answers to the Enterprise: Signals of Expertise in Social Q&A for Business
column9: Elijah Mayfield, Shimei Pan, Jie Lu, Jennifer Lai
column100: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Community analysis and support, virtual or physical; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: The success of internet social question-answering (Q&A) sites has led many businesses to attempt to duplicate this model internally. In such systems, demand for expertise is high; finding high-quality answers quickly is a top priority. Prior work on high-expertise content discovery, though, has focused on large public websites like StackExchange. We conducted a two-phase study to discover the most important differences between these domains. First, we test features from the public domain that rely on metadata, showing that those features do not transfer exactly to the enterprise. Based on this, we then begin an exploration into answer quality prediction without metadata, relying only on textual signals of expertise. Structured as a sociolinguistic annotation study, we show in our second phase that this step adds predictive power in both public and private domains, both as a standalone indicator and as a supplement to user metadata features.

column3: Capturing the Mood: Facebook and Face-to-Face  Encounters in the Workplace
column9: Gloria Mark, Shamsi Iqbal, Mary Czerwinski, Paul Johns
column100: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Organization/office/workplace support
column101: What makes people happy, engaged and feeling challenged at work? We conducted an in situ study of Facebook and face-to-face interactions examining how they influence people’s mood in the workplace. Thirty-two participants in an organization were each observed for five days in their natural work environment using automated data capture and self-report measures. Our results show that online and offline social interactions are associated with different mood experiences, suggesting that they serve different purposes at work. Face-to-face interactions are associated with a happy mood throughout the day whereas Facebook use and being engaged in work contribute to an overall positive feeling at the end of the day. Email use is associated with negative affect and along with multi-tasking, it is associated with a feeling of engagement and challenge throughout the day. This is the first study that examined how offline and online social interactions influence mood in the workplace.

column3: Characterizing and Predicting Postpartum Depression from Facebook Data
column9: Munmun De Choudhury, Scott Counts, Eric Horvitz, Aaron Hoff
column100: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Machine Learning and Data Mining; Social network analysis
column101: The birth of a child is a milestone in the life of parents. We leverage Facebook data shared voluntarily by 165 new mothers as streams of evidence for characterizing their postnatal experiences. We consider multiple measures including activity, social capital, emotion, and linguistic style in participants’ Facebook data in pre- and postnatal periods. Our study includes detecting and predicting onset of post-partum depression (PPD). The work complements recent work on detecting and predicting significant postpartum changes in behavior, language, and affect from Twitter data. In contrast to prior studies, we gain access to ground truth on postpartum experiences via self-reports and a common psychometric instrument used to evaluate PPD. We develop a series of statistical models to predict from data available before childbirth a mother’s likelihood of PPD. We corroborate our quantitative findings through interviews with a sample of the participants. We find that increased social isolation and lowered availability of social capital as manifested on Facebook, are the best predictors of PPD in mothers.

column3: Structuring Collaborative Reflection: A Balance between scripted collaboration and information spaces
column9: Michael Prilla, Thomas Herrmann
